body.p: This document provides an overview of the features contained within HP Helion OpenStack 2.0, including known issues and workarounds for this release:
body.section:
New GUI Installer
HP Helion OpenStack 2.0 introduces a GUI installer for configuring and installing the operating system, the cloud, and OpenStack services. It provides an easy way to populate the configuration files needed to define the Input Model, and uses them to configure and install your cloud. For help using the installer, see the page .
Transport Layer Security (TLS) Support
TLS is now supported for public endpoints. See Enabling TLS for Public Endpoints for more information.
Encryption of sensitive data
In this release, connection details and passwords are encrypted and or protected. See Encryption of Passwords and Sensitive Data for more information.
AppArmor enabled
AppArmor in HP Helion OpenStack 2.0 is installed and enabled on the KVM compute nodes by default. It runs in enforce mode. It enforces mandatory access control policies for the libvirt process. See AppArmor in HP Helion OpenStack 2.0 for more information.
The lifecycle manager only supports American English language
The lifecycle-manager installation process prompts you to select a language. The only supported language at this time is American English.
Local Git repository for config tracking
In HP Helion OpenStack 2.0, a local git repository is used to track configuration changes as well as acting as a repository for the Configuration Processor to gather configuration settings from. The operations work as explained below:
Operations under ~/helion are under the aegis of git. You’ll need to commit any config into git (on the "site" branch) before the Configuration Processor can run it. The script that runs the config processor now guards against uncommitted changes.
Deployment operations are run from a scratch directory that's assembled from various parts (the ansible output of the Configuration Processor and the playbooks). The directory is created using ready-deployment.yml.
All deployment operations should be run from ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible.
The Configuration Processor uses the config files stored in the repo to apply configuration settings. An explanation can be found in this topic.
New UEFI support
HP Helion OpenStack 2.0 includes support for UEFI (which replaces the BIOS on newer servers), while continuing to support Legacy BIOS. Select the required mode on each node through its BIOS settings before beginning the install process. The installer will detect and use the mode you have selected for each node.
Updated HP Helion OpenStack Services
We have included the core set of OpenStack services from the Kilo release with the exception of limitations notated in this document.
More Cinder Backend Options Available
You can now choose between Ceph, VSA, and 3PAR for Cinder backends.
See: Cinder Overview for more details
Neutron LBaaS and FWaaS Extensions
We have implemented networking extensions for load balancing and firewalls. Here is a description of each of these:
LBaaS (Load-Balancing-as-a-Service) is a Neutron extension that introduces a load balancing feature set. HP Helion OpenStack 2.0 includes the V2 version which uses an implementation of HA Proxy but third-party load balancers can be integrated as well. If a third-party driver doesn’t exist for the load balancer you want to use, then LBaaS V2 installing LBaaS V1 instead of V2 is supported.
For more information, see: Load Balancer (LBaaS) Configuration
FWaaS (FireWall-as-a-Service) is a Neutron extension that introduces a firewall feature set. The included reference implementation is using iptables to block traffic but third-party Firewalls can be integrated with this extension into HP Helion OpenStack as well.
For more information, see: Firewall (FWaaS) Configuration
VPNaaS (Virtual-Private-Network-as-a-Service) is a Neutron extension that introduces a vpn feature set. It allows for encrypted traffic between two routers in (potentially) different datacenters hence supporting secure multi Availability Zone architectures for customers.
For more information, see: VPNaaS Configuration
Multiple networks is a feature in HP Helion OpenStack 2.0 that enables bridging of multiple external physical networks to Neutron network. Using this functionality a tenant can dictate the path taken by the data in the physical network outside the cloud. It can also be used for multi-homing to two physical networks.
For more information, see: Multiple External Network Configuration
New Network Configuration Options
Network interface (NIC) bonding with multiple modes will allow you to set up a highly available and performant network infrastructure.
Multi-network support will allow you to bridge multiple external physical networks to a Neutron network. This will enable you to dictate the path taken by the data in the physical network outside of your cloud deployment.
Network separation (both physical and VLAN) will allow you to segregate traffic by type. For example, traffic can be separated into management, tenant, external, and service networks.
NIC Mapping Feature The new NIC mappings feature in HP Helion OpenStack allows the cloud administrator to map network interface names to PCI bus addresses. This is important because for well-understood reasons, Linux can sometimes name the network interfaces in a pseudo-random order. So in a cluster of identical machines, the eth3 device can appear as eth4 on one or more machines in the cluster. Once this erroneous name is determined by the operating system, it will use persistence rules to ensure that the NIC device is called eth4 thereafter. This makes cluster configuration using Helion quite difficult if not impossible, if most machines understand the Management Network to be eth3, but some subset of machines understand that network to be on eth4 ( and whatever was on eth4 is similarly swapped to eth3).
To resolve this, and to ensure that all NIC devices have consistent naming across the entire cloud, HP Helion OpenStack 2.0 includes NIC Mapping facilities. This is a mechanism in the Input Model to define a specific NIC interface for a given PCI address for a given class of machine. Generally, when all of the network interfaces are defined in the Input Model, it is advisable to use the traditional naming, ie ethN. However, if one or more interfaces are not defined in the Input Model (perhaps because the Ansible network is not defined, or because there is a customer-specific network which is outside the scope of Helion), then it is recommended that a different naming convention is used, to prevent the definitions from colliding with existing configuration data. For example, the NIC mapping definitions could use hos0 through hosN rather than eth0 through ethN, bearing in mind that the new naming must be consistent across the entire Input Model.
Monasca-based Monitoring
Monasca is a multi-tenant, scalable, fault-tolerant, monitoring service. It uses a REST API for high-speed metrics processing and querying, and has a streaming alarm and notification engine. In the HP Helion OpenStack 2.0 release, the OpenStack monitoring standard, Monasca, is supported as the HP Helion OpenStack monitoring solution with the following exceptions (which are not implemented):
Transform Engine
Events Engine
Anomaly and Prediction Engine
Monitoring is integrated for the following services: Logging, Neutron, Swift, Ceilometer, Heat, Rabbit, MySQL, HA Proxy, Glance, Cinder, Monitoring of Monasca, Nova, HP Linux for HP Helion OpenStack.
Learn more about Monasca here: Monasca Overview
Monitoring Configuration Options Available for Metrics Database
In this release you will have the option to specify which database platform you want to use for the metrics database. The default option with the installation is Vertica. The opensource alternative is InfluxDB. Learn more about these options here: Configuring the Monitoring Service
Centralized Logging Logging for the services below is enabled in the default configuration. You will have the ability to disable per-service logging as needed.
Logging is integrated for the following services: Nova, Glance, Swift, Neutron, Ceilometer, Monasca, Horizon, Keystone, Cinder, Heat, OpsConsole, DNSaaS, LBaaS, FWaaS, and Trove.
Learn more about Centralized Logging here: Centralized Logging Overview

Limitations in this Release
Installing Swift
Swift installs with the following limitations:
Only one Swift zone is supported.
Monitoring (Monasca) Limitations The monitoring service has the following limitations:
Vertica is the default metrics database option in the install. If you want to use InfluxDB then read Configuring Monasca for more details.
InfluxDB is not configured behind a VIP. It must directly access one node in the cluster.
Backup/restore of Monasca configuration and metrics data is not available.
Issue: Monasca Command-line Client (CLI) Redirect Fails
If you are using the Monasca CLI and you receive the error below, we have included a workaround:
Error: $ monasca metric-list|grep hostname 'ascii' codec can't encode characters in position 1058218-1058219: ordinal not in range(128)
Workaround: PYTHONIOENCODING=utf-8 monasca metric-list | grep hostname
Monasca Forwarder Log Reporting False Errors
There is an issue where the /var/log/monasca/agent/forwarder.log log file will contain many lines containing text like this: 2015-09-23 17:33:34 UTC | ERROR | forwarder | monascaclient.exc(exc.py:60) | exception: Authentication failed.
This is due to an issue where the monasca-agent is attempting to authenticate when it's token has expired. These can be ignored.
Issue: The 'Cinderlm diagnostics monitor' alarm alerts with an 'UNDETERMINED' state
This alert is not always reported but may occur after the system has been running for some time.
Check if any other Cinder related alarms are alerting. If no other other Cinder related alarms are alerting then this alert for the Cinderlm diagnostics monitor alarm can be ignored. If other Cinder related alarms are alerting then follow the mitigation steps described in the Service Alarm Definitions section.
Operations Console (Ops Console) The Operations Console has the following limitations (listed below by menu option in the console):
Dashboard
There are two notification sections for the Storage services. The one in the upper left is the Compute service mislabeled as Storage.
The New Alarms section uses the UTC timezone to determine timeframes regardless of what timezone is in the settings.
The New Alarms section will only display alarms that have a service dimension defined.
Platform Services (HDP Summary) alarm panels will only contain data if the Helion Development Platform services are installed.
Logging Dashboard
There is no auto-logon function, users must use the credentials in the Logging Overview to access the UI.
The Kibana console intermittently will not function correctly if Kibana is on a different network than the Operations Console. If both Kibana and the Operations Console are on the same network then this issue should not present itself.
Alarms
The tile view of alarms with lengthy dimensions does not render cleanly.
Compute Instances
Compute instance utilization metrics are not available.
Networking - Alarm Summary
Alarms may be limited to only those with the dimension "service=networking".
Storage - Alarm Summary
Alarms with the dimension "service=compute" sometimes appear in this list in addition to the "service=block-storage" and "service=object-storage" ones.
HDP - Alarm Summary
This section will only contain data if the Helion Development Platform services are installed.
Masthead Items
The Help and EULA links will not work properly. You can view the Help files here: Operations Console Overview
User information panel fails to load making it so a user cannot update their email address or password.
Issue: The Operations Console does not support alarm pagination
The Operations Console UI does not support >10,000 simultaneous alarm instances. Configuring alarm definitions such that the number of alarms instances exceeeds the 10,000 mark may cause some alarms to not show in the UI. The workaround for this issue is to access those alarms via either the API or the command-line clients.
Centralized Logging Limitations
The Centralized Logging service has the following limitations:
Alarm definition and generation for Kibana and curator are not integrated.
Logging-monitor 'stop' playbook is not integrated.
Issue: The Elasticsearch Cluster Name Must Be Unique
The default Elasticsearch cluster name is set to elasticsearch in the logging configuration files. It is necessary during installation to change this value to a unique name. This step is included in our installation documentation.
The Elasticsearch high/low watermark alarms will show up in "Undefined"
In the Operations Console, the Elasticsearch high/low watermark alarms will show up in the “Undefined” section instead of in the "Logging" section.
Issue: The Heap parameters for Elasticsearch and Logstash are auto-tuned incorrectly
There is an issue where the Heap parameters for Elasticsearch and Logstash are incorrectly auto-tuned. The default values are listed in Configuring the Centralized Logging Service. There is a bug where Ansible is reporting the memory values incorrectly as values that are slightly less than what they actually are. So, for example, if you have 32GB of RAM you should fall into the "Small" auto-tuning category but because of this incorrectly reported value you are actually falling into the "Demo" category. We recommend that you manually modify the heap values on the lifecycle-manager node for systems with the specified amount of RAM in the table below to the values listed. You will edit these values in the logging_possible_tunings section of the file below: ~/helion/my_cloud/config/logging/main.yml
RAM Key elasticsearch_heap_size logstash_heap_size
32GB demo from 256m to 8g from 256m to 2g
64GB small from 8g to 16g from 2g to 4g
128GB medium from 16g to 32g from 4g to 8g
Issue: Logrotate Settings for MySQL, keepalived, and RabbitMQ are Invalid
There is currently a workaround needed on the controller nodes to fix the logrotate settings for the MySQL, keepalived, and RabbitMQ services. The logrotate for MySQL, keepalived and RabbitMQ is being overwritten by an invalid logrotate configuration supplied in the logging-server component. A valid logrotate configuration for these services is supplied in the following files on the deployer: /home/stack/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible
The files in that directory are: mysql: ./roles/FND-MDB/templates/etc/logrotate.d/mysql keepalived: ./roles/keepalived/templates/keepalived.logrotate.j2 rabbit: ./roles/rabbitmq/templates/rabbitmq-server.logrotate.j2
To correct this problem if the above configuration is copied manually into /etc/logrotate.d on the controller nodes to replace the existing configuration then this should correct the logrotate configuration for these services.
Note any variables such as {{ }} need to be replaced correctly. In the case of RabbitMQ and keepalived this can be achieved by editing the logrotate.j2 with a comment and running a reconfigure (rabbitmq-reconfigure.yml and FND-CLU-reconfigure.yml on the deployer)
In the case of MySQL this needs to be corrected manually as below: File ./roles/FND-MDB/templates/etc/logrotate.d/mysql
{ log_dir }}/*.log { daily rotate 7 missingok create 640 mysql adm notifempty compress delaycompress sharedscripts postrotate if test -x /usr/bin/mysqladmin && \ /usr/bin/mysqladmin ping &>/dev/null then roothome=~root /usr/bin/mysqladmin --defaults-file=${roothome}/.my.cnf --socket="{{ server_socket}}" flush-logs fi endscript }
should be copied into /etc/logrotate.d/mysql on the controller nodes and variables replaced to result in this config:
/var/log/mysql/*.log { daily rotate 7 missingok create 640 mysql adm notifempty compress delaycompress sharedscripts postrotate if test -x /usr/bin/mysqladmin && \ /usr/bin/mysqladmin ping &>/dev/null then roothome="$(realpath ~root)" /usr/bin/mysqladmin --defaults-file=${roothome}/.my.cnf --socket="/var/run/mysqld/mysqld.sock" flush-logs fi endscript }
Issue: Unable to Launch Instance from Volume on Horizon Dashboard
In Beta 2 you will not be able to launch an instance from a volume in Horizon. To work around this issue you have two options:
From Horizon Dashboard | Instances page: Launch an Instance and select source as Bootable volume.
Use the OpenStack or Nova client to create the instance.
When using the Launch Instance action in the Volumes table, the Launch Instance Wizard form doesn't get pre-populated with the Volumes option selected, nor does it select the given Volume.
Issue: The Start Instances Option is Available In Horizon for Instances that are Already Started
There is currently an OpenStack bug where the Start Instances option is available in the instance action drop-down even if your instances are already in an Active state.
Restarting lifecycle-manager node leaves Apache2 down
If you restart your Deployer/lifecycle management node, note that Apache2 will not restart on its own. You will need to restart it manually. Heat autoscaling not supported
In HP Helion OpenStack 2.0, the auto-scaling in Heat is not supported because the alarm creation in Ceilometer is disabled. A Horizon create a 'bootable volume' fails UI task
When you navigate to 'volumes' and choose to create a 'bootable volume,' if you do not navigate elsewhere, the attempt to launch an instance from that volume will fail. That is, nothing will happen.
To work around this issue, after choosing to create a 'bootable volume,' refresh the page in the browser and then proceed. Moonshot remote console goes blank after operating system install
If you are using Moonshot compute nodes you may find that their remote console is blank or garbled after the OS install. If affected, you need to make the following change to /etc/default/grub on each affected node, run update-grub and reboot:
Find the line starting with GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX=
Add the following at the end of the value i.e. inside the double quotes: vga=788 console=ttyS0,9600 earlyprint=serial,ttyS0,9600
IPv6 Traffic Not Supported
The HP Helion OpenStack 2.0 release includes firewall rules to prevent non-essential traffic from accessing the physical systems. However, these rules are limited to IPv4 traffic only. In order to prevent unsolicited or nefarious IPv6 traffic, you will need to block IPv6 at your router, or within the infrastructure.
You can disable IPv6 on your operating systems by adding the following lines to /etc/sysctl.conf: net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6 = 1 net.ipv6.conf.default.disable_ipv6 = 1 net.ipv6.conf.lo.disable_ipv6 = 1 Once these have been added, you can either reboot the node or run the following command (as root): # sysctl -p Please refer to your router documentation to block IPv6 traffic from reaching your network at the router.

section.b: Softlockup is observed when attempting to remove many LUNs simultaneously

body.section: If many multipath LUNs are detached from a compute host in rapid succession a softlockup and RCU (read-copy-update) stall may be observed in the kernel log file as follows: Oct 7 12:48:52 hlm kernel: [31164.262063] rport-0:0-2: blocked FC remote port time out: removing target and saving binding Oct 7 12:48:52 hlm kernel: [31164.262859] rport-0:0-0: blocked FC remote port time out: removing target and saving binding Oct 7 12:49:09 hlm kernel: [31181.132369] BUG: soft lockup - CPU#23 stuck for 22s! [systemd-udevd:554] Oct 7 12:49:09 hlm kernel: [31181.133060] Modules linked in: dm_service_time xt_mac xt_physdev xt_set iptable_mangle xt_comment iptable_nat nf_nat_ipv4 nf_nat iptable_raw ip_set_hash_net ip_set nfnetlink vhost_net vhost macvtap macvlan tun veth bridge ib_iser rdma_cm iw_cm ib_cm ib_sa ib_mad ib_core ib_addr iscsi_tcp libiscsi_tcp libiscsi scsi_transport_iscsi md_mod fuse binfmt_misc xt_tcpudp xt_multiport xt_LOG xt_limit xt_conntrack xt_pkttype ip6table_filter ip6_tables iptable_filter ip_tables x_tables 8021q garp stp mrp llc bonding openvswitch gre libcrc32c nf_conntrack_ipv6 nf_defrag_ipv6 nf_conntrack_ipv4 nf_defrag_ipv4 nf_conntrack dm_multipath scsi_dh evdev iTCO_wdt iTCO_vendor_support x86_pkg_temp_thermal intel_powerclamp coretemp kvm_intel kvm crc32_pclmul crc32c_intel ghash_clmulni_intel aesni_intel psmouse aes_x86_64 lrw gf128mul glue_helper ablk_helper cryptd pcspkr serio_raw ioatdma mgag200 dca ttm ipmi_si drm_kms_helper ipmi_msghandler hpilo drm lpc_ich wmi mfd_core agpgart i2c_algo_bit syscopyarea sysfillrect sysimgblt processor i2c_core thermal_sys acpi_power_meter hpwdt button autofs4 ext4 crc16 mbcache jbd2 dm_mod sd_mod sg lpfc qla2xxx crc_t10dif uhci_hcd ehci_pci crct10dif_generic xhci_hcd ehci_hcd scsi_transport_fc hpsa usbcore usb_common scsi_mod be2net crct10dif_common Oct 7 12:49:09 hlm kernel: [31181.133114] CPU: 23 PID: 554 Comm: systemd-udevd Not tainted 3.14.51-1-amd64-hlinux #hlinux1 Oct 7 12:49:09 hlm kernel: [31181.133115] Hardware name: HP ProLiant BL460c Gen9, BIOS I36 05/06/2015 Oct 7 12:49:09 hlm kernel: [31181.133117] task: ffff883fcf0262c0 ti: ffff883f979ca000 task.ti: ffff883f979ca000 Oct 7 12:49:09 hlm kernel: [31181.133118] RIP: 0010:[<ffffffff81514f5b>] [<ffffffff81514f5b>] _raw_spin_trylock+0xb/0x40The associated stack from the softlockup will show the instruction point either holding or attempting to acquire a spinlock. After all the LUNs have successfully detached and the devices have been flushed, the messages will subside. It is recommended that you include a delay when detaching multiple LUNs to avoid the softlockup and RCU stall messages.

section.title: Features in HP Helion OpenStack 2.0
section.p: Core features in the OpenStack Foundation’s Kilo release (as identified below) are enabled in the HPE Helion OpenStack 2.0 standard settings and are included in Helion standard product support.

Non-core services (listed in the Features tables below) are provided as-is. Some non-core services are included in this release to provide early access to features that HPE may support fully in future releases, but HPE cannot guarantee that support will be provided or issues resolved in a future release. Other non-core features are provided in this release for a limited time and may be deprecated in future releases. HPE will attempt to provide guidance and telephone support for these features at its discretion. If you need additional support on any of these features for a specific use case, please contact the Helion professional services team.
